title: 820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
message:
[B]Received condition:[/B]
Tea spill, damage near the NAND area. The Voltage was stuck at 5v.
[ATTACH type="full" width="271px"]60055[/ATTACH] [ATTACH type="full" width="270px"]60056[/ATTACH]

[B]After the cleanup:[/B]
- Cleaned the whole area. There was a lot of crap underneath the U9080, so removed it. 2 pins were gone.
- Connected power, 5V and 200mA, the C9080 was heating. Heard a crack, removed C9080 and C9081.
- Connected power, 19V and 65mA. But all the caps on the PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 are completely short to the ground.

[ATTACH type="full" width="273px"]60057[/ATTACH] [ATTACH type="full" width="272px"]60058[/ATTACH]

Not sure what to do next? 
In past, I have seen multiple A1990 with NAND short issues.

title: 820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
message:
Overvoltage went from PPBUS_G3H to 2V5_NAND, through U9080.
SSD is dead now...

title: 820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
message:
Did I cause this?
What should be done now? I mean, is SSD replacement a viable option?.

In my experience SSD short on this model is becoming one of the most common issues.
I searched on YouTube, didn't find any videos on this.

title: 820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
message: SSD died because of corrosion, not your fault.

title: 820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
message:
Hopeless project.
Apart of NANDs, must replace the controller, which comes in sandwich package.

title: 820-01041 MacBook Pro A1990 - PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 short to ground
message:
That's sad :(
But anyways, thanks for your support.
